pullRequest.body:
the goal of the PR is to clarify the relationship between the following closely related assumptions on a measurable space:
* Being countably generated (`CountablyGenerated`)
* Separating points (`SeparatesPoints`)
* Having a countable separating family of measurable sets (`HasCountableSeparatingOn _ MeasurableSet univ`) 
* Having singletons be measurable (`MeasurableSingletonClass`)

It defines `SeparatesPoints` and registers all implications between combinations of these properties as instances (or rather a minimal set needed to deduce all others). 

It also proves an optimal theorem regarding when a measurable space appears as an induced subspace of the Cantor Space `Nat -> Bool`. This will be used to generalize topological assumptions to measure theoretic ones in some theorems in `MeasureTheory.Constructions.Polish`.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body:
Thanks for all the comments! I think I have implemented all of your suggestions, plus added/edited some docstrings. 

BTW, I changed the definition of `SeparatesPoints` to only require an implication rather than a bi-implication. This is the same since measurable spaces are closed under complement.

:v: Felix-Weilacher can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
Canceled.
bors r+

Thanks!
bors d+

Thanks! My main comment is that you always state that there exists some object with some properties, but you should almost always add a definition for the object instead, and then add lemmas that assert that the def has the properties. It's much easier to use in downstream code that way.
Thanks! Here are a few minor comments.

Thanks!
bors d+

This should be an instance. However, making it one, even with priority 1, causes timeouts in in BorelSpace/Basic.lean

I would appreciate help troubleshooting this.

The issue occurs in this:
```
instance : MeasurableSMul ℝ≥0 ℝ≥0∞ where
  measurable_const_smul := by
    simp_rw [ENNReal.smul_def]
    exact fun _ ↦ MeasurableSMul.measurable_const_smul _
  measurable_smul_const := fun x ↦ by
    simp_rw [ENNReal.smul_def]
    exact measurable_coe_nnreal_ennreal.mul_const _
```
Looking at the TC trace of this, it's pretty wild...

I have been using `enumerateCountable (countable_countableGeneratingSet (α := α)) ∅` for that sequence, for which the property that it generates the space can be deduced from `range_enumerateCountable_of_mem _ empty_mem_countableGeneratingSet` and `generateFrom_countableGeneratingSet`.

It could be a good idea to add a new definition for the sequence. That way we will have an easy way to refer to it. Adding a definition is preferable to adding an "exists" lemma, since we can then easily state as many theorems about it as we want, without having to state each time another exists theorem with the list of all properties.

In summary: I don't think we want that `exists_seq_generateFrom` lemma, but we could use a definition for the sequence.

Can you state this definition in a way that mimics `Set.SeparatesPoints`? That is, with the contraposition of that implication. We have `Set.SeparatesPoints`, `Subalgebra.SeparatesPoints` and now `MeasurableSpace.SeparatesPoints` and they are all essentially the same statement, more or less specialized. It would be nice if they looked similar.

Also please add API for the definition. For example, for two points x, y not equal, we want a definition that gives us a set with x in it and not y, and a lemma stating that it is measurable.

If we change the definition of SeparatesPoints at I suggest, we will also want your current formulation of `separates` as a lemma.
Hmm, I was intentionally mimicking `HasCountableSeparatingOn`, and I do feel that this way of writing it involves less contraposing down the line. Do you still think I should change it?

Well, the precise definition is not that important and your reason is at least as good as mine, so let's keep it.

The best way to design the library (the way that makes it most usable) is to imagine that you won't be able to access the definition further down the line, and that you should interact with it only through lemmas. 
So choose whatever you prefer for the definition, but please provide several simple lemmas about it, such that no matter your choice for the def, we always have the right lemma at hand.
Yes, I understand and apologize for not adding more supporting lemmas initially. I'll get right on that.

What you are really doing here is construct a `MeasurableEmbedding` from `α` to `ℕ → Bool`. Could you add a definition for that embedding? (extract your construction of `f` from the proof).
Then that theorem is simply the statement that a measurable embedding is an equivalence to its range (and hence the theorem may not be needed).
This is incorrect. There is no guarantee that the set `s` in this theorem will be measurable. In fact this will happen if and only if `\alpha` is standard Borel.
I will add to the docstring to clarify this, though.

You are right, sorry for the mistake.
Anyway, my main point is about the code style and not the math: in the proof you are constructing a function which is measurable and injective as a step towards building the equivalence and putting all that in an exists statement. In the next lemma, you are getting the equivalence by using choice and getting a measurable injective function from that.

The better alternative I am trying to describe is something like the following (with better names, and possibly with a different def for e that does not go through exists_seq_generateFrom):
```lean
noncomputable
def e [MeasurableSpace α] [CountablyGenerated α] [SeparatesPoints α] :=
  (exists_seq_generateFrom α).choose

lemma generateFrom_range_e [m : MeasurableSpace α] [CountablyGenerated α] [SeparatesPoints α] :
  m = generateFrom (range (e α)) := (exists_seq_generateFrom α).choose_spec

noncomputable
def f [MeasurableSpace α] [CountablyGenerated α] [SeparatesPoints α]
    (a : α) (n : ℕ) : Bool := a ∈ e α n

lemma injective_f [MeasurableSpace α] [CountablyGenerated α] [h : SeparatesPoints α] :
    Injective (f α) := by
  intro x y hxy
  rw [generateFrom_range_e α] at h
  apply separating_of_generateFrom (range (e α))
  rintro - ⟨n, rfl⟩
  rw [← decide_eq_decide]
  exact congr_fun hxy n

lemma measurable_f [MeasurableSpace α] [CountablyGenerated α] [SeparatesPoints α] :
    Measurable (f α) := by
  rw [measurable_pi_iff]
  refine fun n ↦ measurable_to_bool ?_
  simp only [preimage, mem_singleton_iff, f, Bool.decide_iff, setOf_mem_eq]
  simp_rw [generateFrom_range_e α]
  exact measurableSet_generateFrom $ mem_range_self _

/-- If a measurable space is countably generated and separates points, it is measure equivalent
to some some subset of the Cantor space `ℕ → Bool` (equipped with the product sigma algebra). -/
theorem measurableEquiv_nat_bool_of_countablyGenerated [MeasurableSpace α]
    [CountablyGenerated α] [SeparatesPoints α] :
    Nonempty (α ≃ᵐ range (f α)) := by
  use Equiv.ofInjective _ (injective_f α)
  · apply Measurable.subtype_mk
    exact measurable_f α
  simp_rw [generateFrom_range_e α]
  apply measurable_generateFrom
  rintro _ ⟨n, rfl⟩
  rw [← Equiv.image_eq_preimage _ _]
  refine' ⟨{y | y n}, by measurability, _⟩
  rw [← Equiv.preimage_eq_iff_eq_image]
  simp[f]

/-- If a measurable space admits a countable sequence of measurable sets separating points,
it admits a measurable injection into the Cantor space `ℕ → Bool`
(equipped with the product sigma algebra). -/
theorem measurable_injection_nat_bool_of_hasCountableSeparatingOn [MeasurableSpace α]
    [HasCountableSeparatingOn α MeasurableSet univ] :
    ∃ f : α → ℕ → Bool, Measurable f ∧ Injective f := by
  rcases exists_countablyGenerated_le_of_hasCountableSeparatingOn α with ⟨m', _, _, m'le⟩
  refine' ⟨f α, _, injective_f α⟩
  exact (measurable_f α).mono m'le (by rfl)
```

I agree with making `e` a definition; `exists_seq_generateFrom` was from awhile ago, before `countableGeneratingSet` existed. 

`f`, on the other hand, seems pretty specific to this proof. Perhaps it and the lemmas about it should be `private`?

```suggestion
    (h : ∀ s, MeasurableSet s → (x ∈ s → y ∈ s)) : x = y := hs.separates _ _ h
```

```suggestion
  refine ⟨fun x y h ↦ ?_⟩
```
refine' was used by mathport to stay close to lean3 syntax, but refine is preferred now.

```suggestion
  refine ⟨{y | y n}, by measurability, ?_⟩
```

```suggestion
  refine ⟨map_nat_bool_of_countablyGenerated α, ?_, injective_map_nat_bool_of_countablyGenerated _⟩
```
Here we see the advantage of `refine` over `refine'`: we see which hole is inferred and which remains to prove.

```suggestion
  exact (measurable_map_nat_bool_of_countablyGenerated _).mono m'le le_rfl
```

This theorem is also about the function for which you added a def. Here is a proposition for a proof that uses it directly:
```suggestion
    MeasurableSingletonClass α where
  measurableSet_singleton x := by
    rcases exists_countablyGenerated_le_of_hasCountableSeparatingOn α with ⟨m', _, _, m'le⟩
    rw [← (injective_map_nat_bool_of_countablyGenerated _).preimage_image {x}, image_singleton]
    exact (measurable_map_nat_bool_of_countablyGenerated α).mono m'le le_rfl
      $ MeasurableSet.singleton _
```
The original proof seems more straightforward to me, mostly because the proposed one repeats a lot of the proof of `measurable_injection_nat_bool_of_hasCountableSeparatingOn` anyways.
The rest of the suggestions have been implemented, thanks again!
Fine by me. I agree that my proof repeats the other one quite a bit.
Perhaps name it `map_nat_bool` instead to shorten the name, omitting `of_contablyGenerated`? (only if you don't expect a similar map to be useful under different hypotheses).
Actually I just realized that since it is a def, the name I suggest should not be `map_nat_bool` but `mapNatBool`.
Please undo that change. Removing alpha makes it less readable

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(MeasureTheory.MeasurableSpace.CountablyGenerated): add SeparatesPoints and related theorems

nodes.body: Thanks! My main comment is that you always state that there exists some object with some properties, but you should almost always add a definition for the object instead, and then add lemmas that assert that the def has the properties. It's much easier to use in downstream code that way.

Thanks for all the comments! I think I have implemented all of your suggestions, plus added/edited some docstrings. 

BTW, I changed the definition of `SeparatesPoints` to only require an implication rather than a bi-implication. This is the same since measurable spaces are closed under complement.
Thanks! Here are a few minor comments.

Thanks!
bors d+
